improvement in execution from our go-to-market teams. As an example, the financial services team we created is
allowing us to pursue emerging AI-based industry use cases that we believe our technology best enables. We
also have proof-of-concepts underway for generative AI for CX, a major GenAI use case. Additionally, we are
releasing a series of customer experience AI use cases that customers can quickly implement and are designed
to drive improved results around customer churn, next best action, customer journey, and hyper-personalization.
Our customer success team is doubling down on delivering innovation based, curated to each customer's needs,
and helping to extend the deployment of our technology across their base. In 2025, we are expecting a
meaningful improvement in retention rates over 2024 for both total and on-prem ARR. We started to see
improvement in retention rates in the second half of 2024 and are looking to carry that forward this year. With
these initiatives taking hold, we believe we are well-positioned to execute and return to growth this year.
Just as we made a pivot in 2020 to cloud-first we started to pivot in 2024 towards being the trusted hybrid AI
platform at enterprise scale. Companies have data both in the cloud and on-prem, and we see them becoming
more sophisticated in how they think about leveraging and balancing hybrid capabilities. It's not about choosing
between environments anymore, it's about effectively operating across both in order to meet diverse business
needs, and drive faster decision-making at the scale they require. Our teams are taking our hybrid cloud platform

Let's look at our new Enterprise Vector Store as one example. To get the most value out of generative AI and the

Unstructured data has been difficult to leverage in traditional data management practices, yet is growing three
times faster than other data types. Teradata supports vectors in our Vantage system today for AI applications that

SYNOPSIS:
Here's a structured synopsis of Teradata's Q4 2024 earnings call:

KEY FINANCIAL METRICS:
- Cloud ARR: $609 million
- Total ARR: $1.474 billion
- Cloud ARR Growth: 18% in Q4
- 2025 Guidance: 14-18% cloud ARR growth, flat to 2% total ARR growth

NOTABLE BUSINESS HIGHLIGHTS:
- New partnerships with NVIDIA and strengthened relationships with major CSPs
- Launch of Enterprise Vector Store (in private preview)
- Integration with Amazon Bedrock providing 60+ GenAI use cases
- Recognition in 2025 Gartner Critical Capabilities report (top 5 ranking)
- New customer wins including major Indian life insurance company and Japanese bank
- Microsoft Fabric Workload Hub integration
- Google Cloud Gemini models API integration

MANAGEMENT OUTLOOK AND GUIDANCE:
- Expecting return to total ARR growth in 2025
- Anticipating meaningful improvement in retention rates for both total and on-prem ARR
- Focus on monetizing new AI capabilities and innovations
- Continued investment in hybrid cloud and trusted AI platform development

KEY RISKS/CHALLENGES:
- Challenging year in 2024 requiring significant organizational changes
- CFO Claire Bramley departing March 31st, 2025
- Need to improve retention rates from 2024 levels
- Competitive pressure in the analytics and AI space

STRATEGIC PRIORITIES:
1. Return to total ARR growth
2. Execute on AI/GenAI strategy with hybrid cloud platform
3. Improve go-to-market execution following restructuring
4. Expand AI capabilities and use cases, particularly in enterprise-scale deployments
5. Focus on customer retention and success
6. Continue technology innovation in hybrid cloud and trusted AI

The company appears to be pivoting toward becoming the trusted hybrid AI platform at enterprise scale, building on their earlier cloud-first transition. Management is emphasizing execution and growth recovery in 2025 after a challenging 2024, with particular focus on AI capabilities and customer retention improvement.

both synchronous and asynchronous execution, agent identity and boundaries, a memory service, a gateway to
translate services to MCP‑compatible interfaces, built‑in code execution and web‑browser tools, and an
observability service. Customers are excited about AgentCore, and it frees them up to start deploying agents
more expansively.

completes VMware TC2 conversions up to 80 times faster, it makes it simple to move from .NET Windows to
.NET Linux implementations, reducing licensing cost for .NET applications by up to 40%.
We've also just released Kiro, our new Agentic integrated development environment coding agent. There's a lot of
buzz around Kiro, with several hundred thousand developers using or requesting access in the first couple weeks,
100,000 used in the first five days of the preview.
What struck a chord for developers is that Kiro allows them to do Vibe coding, where developers use natural
language to chat with a coding agent to build code. But unlike other coding agents, where developers don't really
have any structure to build on top of, Kiro allows developers to use natural language to build a spec, and then
automatically updates that spec as they continue to vibe code or interact with Kiro.
This makes it much easier to go from prototyping to production. Customers also like Kiro's event‑driven agent
hooks that act like an experienced developer catching things developers might miss. When developers save a
React component, hooks update the test file. When they modify API endpoints, hooks refresh ReadMe files, when
they're ready to commit, security hooks scan for leak credentials.
It's still very early for Kiro, but it seems clear we're on to something customers love, and Kiro has a chance to
transform how developers build software. I say this frequently, but remember that 85% to 90% of worldwide IT
spend is still on‑premises versus in the cloud. In the next 10 to 15 years, that equation is going to flip, further
accelerated by companies' excitement for leveraging AI.

In Q2, worldwide third-party seller unit mix was 62%, the highest ever, up 100 basis points from Q2 of last year.
We're also closely monitoring the macroeconomic environment, including the impact of tariffs. As Andy
mentioned, our Q2 plan factored in a range of assumptions, not all of which materialized. We will continue to
consider a range of assumptions going forward.
Shifting to profitability. North America segment operating income was $7.5 billion, an increase of $2.5 billion year-
on-year. North America operating margin was 7.5%, up 190 basis points year-over-year. International segment
operating income was $1.5 billion, up $1.2 billion year-over-year. International operating margin was 4.1%, up 320
basis points year-over-year. We're pleased with the strong execution of our operations teams and the positive
experience they delivered for customers.
In Q2, we saw productivity gains in our transportation network, driven by improved inventory placement, strong
leverage on high-unit volumes, and higher levels of in-demand inventory from both first-party and third-party
selling partners.
These factors contributed to faster delivery speeds and lower costs. Outbound shipping costs were up 6% year-
over-year, and continued to grow at a meaningfully slower pace than unit growth, which, as I mentioned earlier,
was up 12% year-over-year.
We're committed to initiatives that further improve our cost structure. Strategic inventory placement drives multiple
benefits, including better in-stock availability, shorter delivery routes, and faster customer delivery times. When
we optimize inventory location, we can consolidate more items for package reducing packaging materials and
costs.
To achieve this, we will continue to improve upon on inbound network, expand our US Same-Day Delivery
facilities, including in rural communities, and implement robotics and automation across our facilities. While year-
over-year improvements in operating margin may fluctuate, we have a purposeful strategy to achieve sustained
progress over time.
Shifting to advertising, advertising revenue grew 22% year-over-year, driven by sponsored products as we saw
strong traffic in our stores. Advertising remains an important contributor to profitability in the North American and
International segments. Our full funnel advertising approach of connecting brands with customers is resonating.
Moving next to our AWS segment, revenue was $30.9 billion, an increase of 17.5% year-over-year. AWS now has
an annualized revenue run rate of more than $123 billion.
During the second quarter, we continue to see growth in both our generative AI and non-generative AI
businesses, as companies turn their attention to newer initiatives, bring more workloads to the cloud, restart or
accelerate existing migrations from on-premise to the cloud, and tap into the power of generative AI.
AWS operating income was $10.2 billion. We did see AWS segment margins decline from a record high of 39.5%
in Q1 to 32.9% in Q2. The largest quarter-over-quarter driver of the decrease, or about half, is due to the
seasonal step-up in stock-based compensation expense driven by the timing of our annual compensation cycle.
AWS margins also saw headwinds from higher depreciation expense as well as unfavorable impacts from year-
over-year fluctuations in foreign-exchange rates. The depreciation expense is a result of our growing investments
in capital expenditures in AWS.

SYNOPSIS:
Here's a structured synopsis of Amazon's Q2 2025 earnings:

KEY FINANCIAL METRICS:
- Revenue: $167.7 billion (+12% YoY excluding FX)
- Operating Income: $19.2 billion (+31% YoY)
- Free Cash Flow (TTM): $18.2 billion
- AWS Revenue Run Rate: $123 billion (17.5% YoY growth)
- Advertising Revenue: $15.7 billion (+22% YoY)

NOTABLE BUSINESS HIGHLIGHTS:
- Record-breaking Prime Day with highest-ever sales and Prime sign-ups
- Nike products returned to Amazon's retail platform
- Added premium brands (Away, Aveda, Marc Jacobs, etc.)
- Expanded Perishables Pilot with 75% new customer adoption
- Deployed 1 millionth robot in fulfillment network
- Major advertising partnerships with Roku (80M CTV households) and Disney
- Significant AWS customer wins including PepsiCo, Airbnb, Nasdaq, Warner Bros. Discovery

OPERATIONAL IMPROVEMENTS:
- 40% increase in direct shipping lanes
- 12% reduction in average package travel distance
- 15% reduction in handling touches per unit
- 30% increase in same-day/next-day deliveries in US
- Expansion of fast delivery to 4,000 smaller cities and rural communities

STRATEGIC PRIORITIES:
1. Accelerating delivery speeds and network efficiency
2. Expanding selection and maintaining price leadership
3. Growing AWS and AI capabilities, particularly through Bedrock and custom chips
4. Advancing automation and robotics integration
5. Expanding advertising reach and capabilities

KEY RISKS/CHALLENGES:
- Uncertainty around tariff impacts on retail prices
- Supply constraints in AWS/AI infrastructure
- Competitive pressure in retail and cloud services
- Potential impact of macroeconomic conditions

The earnings report reflects strong execution across Amazon's core businesses, with particular momentum in AWS's AI initiatives, advertising growth, and operational efficiency improvements in the retail business. Management appears focused on balancing growth investments with operational efficiency while maintaining competitive advantages in key markets.

SYNOPSIS:
Here's a comprehensive synopsis of Teradata's Q2 2025 earnings:

KEY FINANCIAL METRICS:
- Total ARR: $1.49 billion (up 2% YoY)
- Cloud ARR: $634 million (15% constant currency growth)
- Cloud ARR growth guidance maintained at 14-18% for full year
- Improved retention rates in Q2, expected to continue through 2025

NOTABLE BUSINESS HIGHLIGHTS:
- Launched Teradata AI Factory with NVIDIA AI Enterprise integration
- Released Enterprise Vector Store for AI/ML capabilities
- Introduced open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) server
- New partnerships announced with:
  * ServiceNow (data integration)
  * Salesforce (AI agent ecosystem)
  * Fivetran (data pipeline transformation)
- New executive appointments including CFO and Chief Administrative Officer
- Marketing function realignment into TTM and product organizations

MANAGEMENT OUTLOOK AND GUIDANCE:
- Reaffirmed full-year ARR and free cash flow guidance
- Confident in achieving full-year targets
- Expecting continued improvement in retention rates
- Focused on accelerating growth and delivering durable free cash flow

STRATEGIC PRIORITIES:
1. Expanding AI and GenAI capabilities across hybrid environments
2. Strengthening data management and analytics offerings
3. Improving sales execution and customer retention
4. Operating efficiency and margin optimization
5. Building strategic partnerships in AI/ML space

KEY RISKS/CHALLENGES:
- Need to maintain sales execution improvements
- Managing transition to cloud while supporting hybrid deployments
- Competitive pressure in AI/ML space
- Contract renewal timing and customer retention
- Operating expense optimization while investing in innovation

The company appears to be successfully executing its transition to cloud/hybrid offerings while capitalizing on AI opportunities, though maintaining growth momentum and managing the transition remains crucial. Management's tone was confident about meeting full-year targets, supported by improved execution and strategic initiatives in AI/ML capabilities.
